title: Urban Housing Affordability Crisis
description: Rapidly increasing housing costs in major urban areas have made homeownership and even rental housing increasingly unaffordable for middle and lower-income residents.
problemDefinition: Housing costs in major metropolitan areas have outpaced wage growth by significant margins over the past two decades. In many cities, median housing prices are 8-12x median household income, compared to historical norms of 3-4x. This creates severe economic stress, forces long commutes, and contributes to homelessness.
rootCauses: Restrictive zoning laws limiting high-density development
NIMBYism blocking new construction in desirable neighborhoods
Land use regulations increasing construction costs
Limited public transit reducing viable housing locations
Housing treated as investment vehicle driving speculation
Wage stagnation not keeping pace with cost increases
Geographic constraints in coastal cities

commonSolutions.name: Upzone residential areas to allow higher density
strengths: Increases housing supply where demand is highest
Can create more walkable, transit-oriented neighborhoods
weaknesses: Faces fierce political opposition from homeowners
Can accelerate gentrification if not paired with affordability requirements

commonSolutions.name: Rent control and price stabilization
weaknesses: Reduces incentive to build new housing
Creates misallocation (people staying in too-large units)
Benefits primarily current renters, not future ones
Economic consensus suggests it reduces overall supply

commonSolutions.name: Subsidized affordable housing construction
strengths: Can be paired with supportive services
weaknesses: Often concentrated in less desirable areas
Requires sustained political will and funding

historicalAttempts.approach: Strict rent control combined with limited upzoning
historicalAttempts.outcome: Housing crisis worsened; median rents among highest in nation despite controls

historicalAttempts.approach: Citywide elimination of single-family zoning (2040 Plan)
historicalAttempts.outcome: Early implementation; some increase in multi-unit construction, long-term impacts TBD

historicalAttempts.approach: Large-scale public housing (60% of residents in social housing)
historicalAttempts.outcome: Widely considered successful; high quality, mixed-income housing; requires sustained political commitment

constraints.budgetary: Public housing construction costs $300k-$800k per unit in high-cost cities. Subsidies at scale require tens of billions annually.
constraints.political: Homeowners are politically organized and oppose density increases. Developers often resist affordability requirements. Federal housing funding has declined.
constraints.logistical: Construction capacity is limited. Skilled labor shortages. Permitting processes take years. Infrastructure (water, transit) may need expansion.

ethicalConsiderations: Housing as human right vs. property rights of current owners
Generational equity: policies favoring current homeowners vs. future residents
Spatial justice: concentration of affordable housing in specific areas
Gentrification and displacement of long-time residents
Environmental impact of sprawl vs. density

title: Healthcare Access and Affordability
description: Millions of Americans lack adequate health insurance or face crippling medical costs, while healthcare spending consumes an increasing share of GDP without commensurate health outcomes.
problemDefinition: The U.S. spends nearly 18% of GDP on healthcare, far more than peer nations, yet millions remain uninsured or underinsured. Medical debt is a leading cause of bankruptcy. Life expectancy lags behind other developed nations despite higher spending.
rootCauses: Employment-based insurance system leaves gaps for unemployed and self-employed
High administrative costs due to fragmented payer system
Fee-for-service incentivizes volume over outcomes
Pharmaceutical pricing lacks negotiation constraints
Consolidation among providers reducing competition
Defensive medicine and malpractice costs
Chronic disease prevalence driven by lifestyle factors

commonSolutions.name: Single-payer universal healthcare (Medicare for All)
strengths: Eliminates administrative waste from multiple payers

commonSolutions.name: Public option competing with private insurance
strengths: Expands coverage without eliminating private insurance
weaknesses: Risk of adverse selection (sickest gravitate to public plan)
May not achieve full cost savings of single-payer
Requires careful design to avoid undercutting private market

historicalAttempts.approach: State-level individual mandate and subsidized exchange (Romneycare)
historicalAttempts.outcome: Achieved near-universal coverage; served as model for ACA; costs remain high
Universal coverage at lower cost than U.S.; faces wait time issues and underfunding pressures

historicalAttempts.approach: Multi-payer system with mandatory insurance and strong regulation
historicalAttempts.outcome: Universal coverage; costs lower than U.S. but rising; preserves private insurance role

constraints.budgetary: Single-payer estimates range from $28-$36 trillion over 10 years. Current system costs ~$50 trillion. Net savings uncertain.
constraints.political: Private insurance industry employs millions and spends heavily on lobbying. Voters fear losing current coverage. Congressional gridlock.
constraints.logistical: Transitioning 180 million people from employer insurance. Retraining for displaced insurance workers. Rate-setting for all services. Provider participation.

ethicalConsiderations: Healthcare as right vs. market good
Rationing and wait times vs. ability to pay
Allocation of expensive treatments with marginal benefits

title: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation
description: Rising global temperatures and extreme weather events threaten ecosystems, infrastructure, and human wellbeing, requiring both emissions reduction and adaptation strategies.
problemDefinition: Global temperatures have risen ~1.1°C above pre-industrial levels, with current trajectory pointing to 2.5-3°C by 2100. This brings increased extreme weather, sea level rise, agricultural disruption, and ecosystem collapse. Requires both reducing emissions and adapting to locked-in changes.
rootCauses: Fossil fuel dependence for energy, transportation, manufacturing
Externalized costs: carbon emissions impose costs on society, not emitters
Path dependence: trillions invested in fossil fuel infrastructure
Global coordination problem: benefits of action are global, costs are local
Short-term political incentives vs. long-term problem
Economic growth model dependent on energy consumption
Developing nations' aspirations to industrialize

commonSolutions.name: Carbon pricing (tax or cap-and-trade)
strengths: Market-based: lets economy find cheapest reductions
Can be revenue-neutral or fund green investments
Aligns private incentives with social costs
weaknesses: Hard to set right price level
Risk of capital flight without global coordination
Takes time to shift behavior and infrastructure

commonSolutions.name: Renewable energy subsidies and mandates
strengths: Politically more palatable than carbon taxes
Costs of renewables have fallen dramatically
weaknesses: Intermittency requires backup power or storage
May lock in current technologies vs. better future ones

commonSolutions.name: Regulatory mandates (vehicle emissions, building codes, etc.)
strengths: Can achieve specific targets with certainty
weaknesses: Piecemeal approach may miss cheapest reductions

historicalAttempts.approach: Revenue-neutral carbon tax starting at $10/ton CO2
historicalAttempts.outcome: Reduced emissions 5-15% while maintaining economic growth; rebates addressed regressivity

historicalAttempts.approach: Cap-and-trade system (EU ETS) covering major emitters
historicalAttempts.outcome: Reduced covered emissions ~35% since 2005; price volatility and free permit issues
Renewables now ~50% of electricity; very expensive; coal generation persisted until recently

constraints.budgetary: IEA estimates $4 trillion/year investment needed globally to reach net zero by 2050. Adaptation costs for developing nations: $140-300 billion/year by 2030.
constraints.political: Fossil fuel interests resist change. International coordination difficult. Voters resist higher energy costs. Developing nations demand equity. Timelines exceed electoral cycles.
constraints.logistical: Transforming global energy system in 25 years unprecedented. Grid upgrades. Supply chains for clean tech. Workforce transition. Technology deployment at massive scale.

ethicalConsiderations: Intergenerational justice: current benefits vs. future harms
Global equity: developed nations caused problem, developing nations most vulnerable
Just transition: protecting workers in fossil fuel industries
Rights of future generations and non-human species
Tradeoffs between mitigation and adaptation spending
